title: Hong Kong (prop) vs USA (opp) - WSDC 2019 -
description:
In art and popular culture, THBT creating new lead characters for minorities (eg Hancock, Black Panther is better than recasting them in existing roles already played by other actors/communities (eg Ghostbusters, The Little Mermaid).

USA Debate is the country's World Schools Debating Championship program and is sponsored by the National Speech & Debate Association. 

The coaches of the National team are Aaron and Cindi Timmons (Cindi also serves as Team Manager). 

The USA team trains for the World Championship each year at the Global Debate Symposium, held at Colorado College, in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
motion: This house supports the creation of new minority characters over the recasting of existing characters with minority actors.

title: Vietnam WSDC 2023 Semi Finals - Malaysia vs USA
description:
#debate #WSDC #WSDC2023
Malaysia vs USA / Semi Finals / Vietnam WSDC 2023
Proposition: Malaysia
Opposition: USA
Info Slide: A typical nuclear family is composed of two partners with children. In some countries a significant and vocal part of the LGBTQ+ movement are actively advocating settling down and forming nuclear families.
Motion:
This House believes that the LGBTQ+ community should actively embrace the nuclear family ideal

Opp won

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAntmD_yHPRCPBuUVQujKcdczKF8ccSgn
motion: This house supports the LGBTQ movement actively embracing the nuclear family ideal.

argument_units.text: Being a parent is the most rewarding thing many people can hope for. It is a desire to watch your child grow from a baby who speaks to the world semifinals, for example. Queer people are no different from that. But we think uniquely under the side of proposition where their choice to have a family is empowered and when they're normalized in the status quo, that is a world we yearn for. We're so proud to propose.

Before I forward two substantive arguments within the speech, on to set up four things. One, we support the LGBTQ movement actively embracing the nuclear family ideal. What does this look like? It means that they embrace the concept that LGBTQ individuals are capable of having a nuclear family. Note that this is quite similar to what the LGBTQ movement did with the free love movement when it came to doing things like trying to co-opt marriage equality for queer individuals. B, we think the messaging the movement would then adopt is they would advocate for the legitimisation of LGBTQ individuals being able to do things like have a family. So they focus on creating accessibility pathways, for example, making it far easier for queer individuals to adopt a child or have a biological one through IVF. Secondly, note that there are many iterations of what the nuclear family ideal looks like. So at this precipice in the debate, we think the LGBTQ movement would frame the ideal through the lens of queerness. For example, having the ability to have a family isn't only restricted to heterosexual individuals. But note that this doesn't mean that the community will have to advocate only for family at the expense of other things. We think they can still do it. We think they can still advocate for queer individuals having access to things like marriage. It doesn't have to be exclusively family.

On our side, we would do things like focus on dismantling the stereotypes surrounding queer individuals and their ability to have a family. For example, that having a mother and father isn't necessary in order to raise a child successfully, queer individuals can do this too. Thirdly, what is the actual comparative that opposition needs to defend in this debate? Note that in the context of the status quo, we've already been able to secure things like marriage rights for queer individuals in many liberal democracies, but the one stereotype that we have yet to defeat in the status quo is the notion that LGBTQ individuals are incapable of having a family because they're going to corrupt our children. Note that the stance of having a nuclear family isn't one that exists in a vacuum. It is a lifestyle choice that the movement is going to prescribe onto individuals. Therefore, on the side of opposition, they also need to prescribe an alternate ideal lifestyle for LGBTQ individuals to pursue. Note then on our burden. Insofar as we prove that, them choosing to co-opt a nuclear family ideal is able to empower the ability of LGBTQ individuals to pursue a family and uniquely dismantles the harmful stereotypes that are imposed onto them in the status quo, that is enough to take this round. Two arguments. One, on how the adoption of a queer family model is the best form towards humanising members of the queer community. And secondly, while we maximise the choice of members in the community to have access to things like family planning.

On the first argument, three parts. One, note that the adoption of the family unit for many social movements has actually been an extremely strategic move, because a vast majority of the social movements in the status quo were successful largely because they chose to integrate the family unit into their models of hypocrisy. For example, the civil rights movement saying that all individuals, regardless of race, should have the ability to do things like have children. But second of all, it was on severity. The only way that they get access to their arguments about humanization is if they buy into the kind of strict, rigid nuclear family that is so problematic. On buy-in, on individuals, we win. title: WSDC 2017 - Round 3 - Team Canada vs Team Wales - Women in Religious Institutions
description:
World Schools Debating Championships 2017 in Bali, Indonesia. 

Round 3

Motion: This house would remove tax-exempt status from religious organisations that refuse to appoint female leaders.

Proposition: Team Wales 

Opposition: Team Canada

This motion was pre-prepared. 

Team Wales won the debate on a 3-0 decision.
motion: This house would remove tax-exempt status from religious organisations that refuse to appoint female leaders.

argument_units.text: A doctrine that says that women cannot be is nothing less than slander, but just on half of the women race, but on all of the women race. That's why Team Rose is proud to stand for the team line that we will not grant privilege and favour to those who willfully slander women.

What are we proposing? A five-part model. Firstly, organisations who wish to keep their statutory status should appoint a large number of female leaders reasonably quickly at every level of their hierarchies. And obviously we would not be happy with just one or two token candidates. Secondly, insofar as we get tax revenue from this policy, the money will be spent disproportionately to help women and will also be part of the international aid budget. Thirdly, given that international policy requires a reasonably sophisticated tax code and state apparatus. We would imagine that this happens in primarily Western liberal democracies. But we say that our principles apply in any country in which opposition can prove to us that such tax codes exist. Fourthly, this debate presumes that the state and the religion are separate, so it does not occur in democracies like Saudi Arabia or Iran, but it does in secular states like India, South Africa and most of Europe. Fifthly, we realise that some of these institutions carry out genuine charitable activities and we support this. So we will therefore make all charitable activities tax deductible, just as we allow charitable work by corporations to be deductible. Just to be clear however, we will ensure that these activities are genuinely charitable, so things like missionary work do not apply. However, full day and exercise such things would. Let's be clear, these normalizations would still be tied to property, assets, investments and income.

So we bring you a three part case. Firstly, I will explain to you why tax exemption is a privilege and not a right. Secondly, I will tell you how we get more female leaders from the R7 House. And lastly, my second speaker will be talking on how we

empower women all across the globe. On to my first argument. Why tax exemption is a privilege and not a right. We think it is high time to update the RK policies with the favour of religion in order to reflect more modern values of equality. We believe that the government should have every right to tax women's coordination pursued precisely through the first view on the principle of reciprocity. Religious institutions could not exist without the support continually provided to them by the government. They could not hold poverty if the government did not hold up the law and the police force which we all pay for. More importantly, they could not exist without the right to free association, speech and freedom of religion, which is upheld by the police and the judiciary, which, once again, we all pay for. It is abhorrent that religions can derive such benefit from the taxes we pay and the laws which we uphold, and they do not contribute their fair share to upholding them. Secondly, as long as religions don't pay tax, the burden on ordinary people is dramatically increased. The general population pays for the billions of dollars of government spending, and whilst some of this burden falls on the wealthy, a lot of it does fall on ordinary, wealthy-class people, the poor and women. In our world, it becomes possible to alleviate this burden when religions pay fair taxes. Team Canada will leave poor women to make up for the greed of religions. So, to be clear, the premise of this debate is that religions owe an enormous debt to society and to the government and should have been paying taxes for it very long time. However, just as the government has taken it away, so too can the government forgive. With this, it could be reasonable for the government to forgive this debt if the religion helps it to promote certain policies. In the same way, crediting by forgiven debt is the debt of the enemy. However, it is reasonable for the government to forgive the debt of religions, since those religions help to promote certain useful policies. What we propose is to do something of a deal with religious organizations that is unprecedented for such deals. We already give Times Square this to corporations who promote affirmative action in the second or combat climate change. We will forgive the debt of religions which promote female leaders. That's what we stand for.
Do you believe that the role of men in religious institutions is more important than the role that women play?
We don't think men are more important than women in religion. We think that religions have been explicitly stated that men should move how women,

or should be part of the government in religious institutions. Therefore, we think that religious institutions have an equal playing field, have an equal ground. That's what we stand for. heroes. Now onto our second question. So it's time to know, why is policy resolved in the appointment of more women? Firstly, how does our membership incentivize change within doctrines? Let's outline in my example the money involved here will be a sufficient incentive for change within the religion. Note that this is an extremely large sum of money that we're talking about. It would impact religious institutions both on a small and on a large scale. On a large scale, when the Catholic Church has to pay tax on the CC channel, when it has to pay property tax on trying real-estate materials in every major city in Europe, the church that currently exists will not be financially viable, as any reserved religious organization would not be able to exist as it currently does. In addition, we imagine that for most religious leaders, the thought of losing their jobs, their buildings, and other pet projects they've been working on for a long period of time will be a sufficient incentive for them to change their policy. Furthermore, we think that on a smaller scale, with independence laws and smaller congregations, they will also come by without policy. We imagine that it is most likely also that for inferior leaders, that will close down entirely, as would be the case given that they will die of small donations and tax exemptions too. Furthermore, we think this incentive would also speak to particularly hardline and devout leaders within the movement. Why have that aspect? Because every program that a hardline leader wants to promote still requires money. Launching new missionary efforts, converting new funders, or introducing new education programs in order to save souls, these things all require money. You see, no reason why they would prioritize not appointing female leaders over anything other than a bit of their doctrine. In addition, we think this is especially true given that we imagine that at least some religious organizations will have a private policy and will then keep their money and their missionary benefits. Given that happens, any church where you please honor that we refuse to comply, this is being outcompeted and losing followers as a result. Now, we think that this policy, this chain, will be fairly easy for leaders to make within their religions. Why? Two precisely. Firstly, if a religious leader was to introduce a policy, even if they are doing so for purely financial motives, it is very easy for them to claim that they are doing it for genuine doctrinal reasons. That's why when Pope Francis wanted to soften the church's stance on homosexuality, he was able to back himself up by claiming that the Bible already supported him. The Jew on Jesus' son on the mountain said, if a man is gay and loves God, who am I to judge him? Thus he justified an entirely new policy with reference to old, already existing doctrine. Can you imagine something similar would happen when appointed human leaders. He perhaps would quote Jesus' words, but the person with the most knowledge should be the leader, or any other thing of sorts. This is especially easy given that religion can be very contradictory, and leaders can choose the interpretation that most believers get pregnant with women in order to prepare for the equality, while still adhering to their religion. The second reason why this change will be easy to make. There are men inside a school who want to change doctrine. Who want to change doctrine. This is for two reasons. Firstly, they want more confidence. They will get back if they incorporate other values into their religion. title: WSDC 2018 R3: India vs Estonia
description:
R3: "This House regrets the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding experience."

India PROP vs Estonia OPP

3:0 India won
motion: This house regrets the glorification of motherhood.

But girls, right from when they are born, are told by the men in their families that this is what you're going to be. But finally, it removes the choice to leave relationships, to leave families, to leave marriages. Because even saying that you don't enjoy being a mother is something that's shocking. Oh, what? They can do things like taking care of their money. They can do things like taking care of careers. And it's based on disproportionate burdens on women. They have to take care of the dishes. So firstly in my speech I'm going to talk about an engaged side propositions case and show how they're debating not the rewarding appreciation motion but rather a glorification, rather a due motion, then clarifying this debate up and then talking about my construction material, the most important things in this debate, which is firstly, how women's societal position is actually much better under our side when mothers are appreciated for doing what they do, and secondly, how we get better parenting and how we get better parents and better feeling parents overall, who appreciate what they're doing.

But now firstly, let's clear up this debate. What does exactly rewarding mean? It means that a parent, that a mother, is getting some positive benefits out of motherhood. For example, feeling good, getting love in the future from their baby, or feeling that their baby is giving them some positive emotions, or that they're getting some personal development out of it, but this is an experience that helps them to grow and be a better person. This debate, however, is not about the way the psychoposition wants to characterize it and say that females, whether females should be suppressed by society and should be denied the ability to not have a baby and should be denied the ability to get information or education, because obviously we oppose that too. but what this debate actually means is that when you decide to have a baby, when you decide that motherhood is good, then we should rather perceive it as an enriching experience, as rather a rewarding experience to you as a society. So now, what did sarcopoposition say? That this is never rewarding and that glorification harms women and pressurises them to become mothers since it basically makes the duty to have children better. title: WSDC 2018 Round 3 - Bangladesh v Singapore
description: Rd 3 of the World Schools Debating Championships in Croatia. Bangladesh wins 3-0 vs Singapore on the motion: TH regrets the widespread belief that motherhood is a rewarding Experience.
motion: This house regrets the narrative that motherhood is a rewarding experience.

argument_units.text: I now invite the first speaker of cyber position to deliver their speech inside of the chamber. For far too long, I have been deceived by women to believe in the utopia of motherhood. That the sacrifices they make are minuscule to the rewards that they will generate. Where does this belief come from? It comes from the narrative that motherhood is a holy process, a process that can do you no harm. We change that from team proposition. Three burdens in our case.

First, why this narrative is false in the majority of cases. Second, why this narrative is false in the majority of cases. Second, why this narrative is coercive and harmful to women. And finally, how this narrative is harmful to the children these women bear. What does our world look like? Our world looks like that if you as a mother or an expectant mother want to find intrinsic value in the small things like your child walking or your child speaking his first words, then we are perfectly okay with that. We are not okay with you being coerced into believing that those minuscule moments of happiness cancel out every single sacrifice you make along the way for that to happen. Three arguments in my speech. First, why the narrative is false. Second, why this narrative is forced. And finally, the lasting effect it has on the child. Before I move on to Sher. Telling people that social work is rewarding equally causes them to become social workers. Do you therefore oppose this narrative? Yeah, sure. If any narrative goes absolutely unopposed in society and becomes something that you cannot oppose or cannot opt out of, then sure, we're happy to oppose that narrative as well, or find counter-narratives thereof.
First argument, why the narrative is false.

Because we understand that looking at your child succeed, or his first steps, can bring you happiness. But that's not the debate, whether you can garner small moments of happiness from your child. This debate is about whether that happiness weighs up in comparison to every single sacrifice that you make along the way. Because when is something rewarding? Something is only rewarding when the output or the outcomes of that action outweigh the efforts or the sacrifices that you make along the way. What do these sacrifices look like? First, the physical sacrifices. Now take it back. You as an expectant mother go through nine months of the worst hell that you'll ever experience in your entire life. You wake up every morning feeling nauseous, feeling the need to vomit, not only your food but also your blood. You feel like your food habits and what you want to do, where you want to go, what you want to see, all of these are being deeply affected and deeply changed by the concept of that pregnancy. You spend sleepless nights because your body's hormones have gone haywire and you literally cannot function throughout the entire day because you are exhausted, because your body feels like a bag of bones and flesh and not a functioning human body. In labor, you're going through the most painful experience known to man. A human woman's cervix will expand nine times its regular size when you're giving birth.
Imagine that amount of pain, that amount of excruciating pain,

not for an instant, but for 14 hours, for days, for days, in the cases of longer labors. Imagine all of that pain happening to you, and you simply believing that it doesn't happen. But the pain is also psychological, because this is a unique experience. We as men, or we as husbands and sons, cannot relate to what our mothers go through, our sisters go through when they are going through this pain. We cannot relate, we cannot console them in any effective manner whatsoever. These people psychologically when they are giving birth, when they are bearing children feel weak and feeble. Feel like they are victims to their circumstances and there is nothing that they can do about them. No medicine will comfort them as much as they want to. But finally, the harms are also to your identity. So even after that child has been born, you are forced to give up all of your identities in favor of motherhood. You lose out on your careers because your identity as a businesswoman or your identity as a politician comes inside your family, comes secondary to your identity and your responsibilities as a business woman or your identity as a politician comes inside your family, comes secondary to your identity and your responsibilities as a mother. But then, why are the rewards that you gain not sufficient? Because these harms are objective, but the rewards are, the harms that you incur are always objective, but the rewards are often subjective. The happiness that you gain from your child is not always rewarding. One, your child might not be successful but even if he is successful he might not follow exactly in your footsteps, grow up exactly how you imagined him to be. This child, but in the vast majority of cases, even if this child succeeds you have no ownership about that success because society tells you that these are all personal efforts of that child in and of itself. The conclusion of this is that the narrative that says that it is all worth bringing life into this world is simply false. Why is it bad to preach an incorrect narrative? Because the person that is making that decision is deceived into that narrative. This is the exact same reason why we don't allow things like false advertising or fake news. Because they establish a version of reality that is simply not true. But more importantly, this specific narrative is one that cannot be countered. Especially in developing countries where you are told that it's a requirement for women to have children. It's a responsibility of women to have children. This narrative is inescapable and thus it harms these women the most. Yes? The motion clearly calls for you to oppose motherhood as a whole. Do you not think it is convenient for you to just shrink your case to coercion? So, we don't think it calls for us to oppose motherhood as a whole. It calls for us to oppose the belief that motherhood is rewarding and only a rewarding experience. They cannot misconstrue the motion to their benefit. Second argument about why this narrative is coercive. What is coercion? Coercion is a form of manipulation that implicitly pressurizes you to do something. What are the tenets of coercion? Firstly, an informational asymmetry. Even when that information exists, that this isn't a rewarding experience, that is hidden from you by society, by means of that larger narrative, that this is rewarding. But secondly, also the lack of opt-out mechanism, why you cannot abandon that child. Even once you find out that this is not a rewarding experience, you cannot shirk your responsibilities. You can only embrace them further. Why is this coercion unique to all other forms of coercions that they will likely talk about in their case? One, the scale. Because compare this to the coercion that advertising or fake news chooses. Advertising coerces you into buying something. Fake news coerces you into voting for a certain party. This coercion literally coerces you to give up all your pre-existent identities and form a new identity. An identity which you do not understand the implications of. But secondly, also the effect. So other forms of coercion have a widespread effect and do not cater to you as an individual. But this is an individual, this
affects you on an individual scale where you're forcing every moment, every waking moment to buy into that narrative. How does this coercion work? From the very moment that child gets her first

period, that is a cause for celebration. Because that child is now ready to bear women. Your parents, your colleagues, your co-workers, all of them tell you that being a woman is an amazing thing. It's a glorious thing. And all of these harms are minuscule compared to that. Art and media tell you that the holy grail of womanhood is motherhood. That all of your identity has to be tied to that one single thing. What are the impacts of this? This impacts you in a couple of different ways. Because your entire identity being hinged on motherhood tells you that motherhood is all you need to be happy. So it's okay to give up that six-figure salary job. It's okay to give up that European vacation. Because you know what? You're a mother. And being a mother is all that will garner you happiness. But more importantly, you're also pushed on more responsibility because if something is rewarding, you have to work for that reward. So if the rewards are greater, your responsibility is greater. This is the way in which society tells you that it's the responsibility of women to look after their children. It's the responsibility of women to ensure that their children are brought up. And this narrative is a key component of that. We think that motherhood is great, but it's not as great as society will tend to inflame it to be.

and I would like to invite the first speaker of the opposition to deliver their speech. Members of the House, in society today, we tell males that every job they do is rewarding. title: WSDC 2019 Round 3 — Greece vs. Singapore
description:
Round 3 of the 2019 WSDC, with Greece on Prop and Singapore on Opp.

The motion was: In art and popular culture, THBT creating new lead characters for minorities (e.g. Hancock, Black Panther) is better than recasting existing roles already played by other actors/communities (e.g. Ghostbusters, The Little Mermaid).

Singapore won on a 3-0 decision.
motion: This house prefers creating new lead characters for minorities over recasting minorities in pre-existing roles.

argument_units.text: From Black Panther to Moana to Jedi Ray, roles written to be played by minorities uniquely represent their experience, empowering minority viewers and avoiding backlash. We don't want a world where existing roles pretend to be representative by adding a sprinkle of minorities just in the actors that play them, because we on Proposition believe that minorities are more than just different characteristics like skin color and gender. They're about different stories.
Three points in opposition today. Firstly, on empowering minorities. Secondly, on public perception. And in my partner's speech, thirdly, on minority actors.

Before that, let's define the notion. By art and popular culture, we're talking about movies, TV shows, theatre, musicals, everything, right? Secondly, by minorities, we're talking about racial, ethnic, religious, sexual orientation minorities. And we would also include women because of the societal oppression they face. Thirdly, by moving characters... Is this a clarification? Yes. Okay, sure.
Do you think that a misogynistic character should continue being portrayed as misogynistic?

I don't think this is affected by the notion in any way. Presumably, this would be the same on both sides. If you want to clarify the next speech, you should do so. By using characters, we're talking about having different names, backstories, personalities, and behaviors that follow new global experts, like Black Panther, for example. But we think they can still exist in the same universe as the previous one. Like, for example, when Jedi Ray was written specifically as a minority, but into the existing Star Wars franchise. By recasting minority actors, we mean putting them into remakes or sequels with existing

new characters returning. We think the criteria for this debate should be, when do we support a movement regarding diversity in popular culture? Firstly, when it leads to more meaningful representation of minorities, because we want to empower them in a society that has been holding them down. Like, for example, we would be against white actors playing black characters with black eyes. And secondly, when it leads to long-term acceptance, because we want to protect minorities Like, for example, we would be against white actors playing black characters with blackness. And secondly, when it leads to long-term acceptance, because we want to protect minorities from harmful societal perceptions.

But now moving into my first argument about empowerment, where we claim that we empower minority communities because we tell their stories in mainstream media. This argument will prove that meaningful representation only comes when you see someone like you having their own story and character and not just having the same skin colors. So why do we reflect minority experiences more meaningfully? We think first thing, this happens because we write a new character, right? With a backstory, complexity and nuance. This means that as a writer, you have to tell a compelling story about this person. On Up, you base your character on the old version, and you don't write a new backstory with new character traits, since the character already exists. For example, when Hermione in the Harry Potter musical was cast as black, nothing changed about her character. She didn't tell the story of the young black girl. The only thing that changed was her skin color. Secondly, on our side, you adapt other characters to that minority. When you write a minority character, you have to write into the script the relationship that exists between minorities in that show, like for for example, like family relationships in Black Panther, but also relationships with other majority characters. And thus you portray the complexity of the experiences that are unique to minorities, right, in society. We think that often you recast, you don't have to consider minority experiences in a meaningful way. Because instead, the minority is an afterthought into a pre-existing story. They are assimilated, they are unimportant. Listen, we're not saying that we get a perfectly nuanced Hollywood on our side. We're reasonable. But we think on the comparative, opposition is far more likely to be shallow and stereotyping of these minorities. Why? Two reasons. Firstly, because of the visibility of what you change on up. Viewers already know the original story. They know what James Bond is meant to be about. And thus, what you add when you put a minority into that role sticks out like a sore thumb. It's thus perceived as how stereotypes will also be perceived. This is basically how, in the new female reboot of Ghostbusters, they added period jokes, simply because the new characters were women. This leads to stereotyping, because you necessarily have to change specific things to indicate that a minority doesn't have it. But secondly, on our side, we can reflect positive societal change through lead roles. Society has largely become much more accepting, much more open to minority narratives. And we can have pop culture that is celebratory of minority identities. Like Moana, for example, which celebrates indigenous identities. Why is all of this important? Because we think we get much more meaningful representation. Indigenous girls are told that they can be their own Disney princesses with Moana, and not just the same little mermaid, just with darker skin. Their culture can be celebrated in the mainstream. And even if this doesn't appear to be a significant difference on the outside, because you still have the minority's visual characteristics displayed, we think carrying with that the unique experience and narratives holds all of the crux of what representation truly is. In our world, minority stories are told with intent and caution, and not just as an afterthought. Minorities are told that they matter for who they are, instead of just being told to be content with seeing their skin colour on TV. But now moving into

my second argument, about how we lead to more positive perceptions of minority stories because we get less backlash. Before that, any points? Okay, this argument will prove that when we create newly enrolled, we get less angry majority, like less angry privileged people, and therefore have more exposure of minority stories. So how do people pursue new minority entertainment on our side? Minority, they're seen as a new story and a narrative with unique characters. This means that there is an incentive for people to watch it, for a few reasons. Firstly, but before I tell you about those, yes?
Given the incentive to cater to the majority, why would writers on your side be incented to create the same shadowy and reductive portrayals of minority characters?

Listen, I told you, even if this is true, we can see that Hollywood isn't perfect and has to cater to some extent to an oppressive narrative. But it's much better when you keep around the unique experiences of what makes someone a minority, and not just the skin color, not just the stereotypes, right? But continuing on with my argument, we think people are unlikely to watch these movies on our site for reasons like liking the gender, like the genre for example. Like if you like action movies, you're likely to go and watch Black Panther. But also, things like having big Hollywood ads and exposure, seeing your favorite actor, minority or not, on a movie poster. And we can still benefit from things like franchises, like Star Wars, creating new minority leads. What happens on Up when you read Hots? Firstly, you're more likely to get backlash. Listen, we're not saying that people are outright and explicitly racist, but we think people in an oppressive society are're more likely to get backlash. Listen, we're not saying that people are outright and explicitly racist, but we think people in an oppressive society are much more likely to feel anger when they feel like their favorite character is being co-opted by political correctness. These same people may be open to thinking Black Panther is awesome and saying the catchphrases of Wakanda, they just don't want you to take James Bond away. We're not defending these people, but we think their anger perpetuates harmful narratives. What is the impact of this? When hardcore fans of original franchises are angry, they do things like spread bad publicity, through Twitter hashtags, through online ratings. Like when the female group of Ghostbusters rated very poorly on Rotten Tomatoes and ended up not selling much in theatres. On our side, you get more exposure. You're more likely to see these stories and think of minority experiences as important. We don't want to live in a world where entertainment of minorities is disregarded because it's the second and worst version of the original role. Stand with me. of the original vote. Stunned vote.

I then seek the contribution to the relation and now call for the first speaker of the opposition. I think it is ironic for a side that claims they want equality to insist that minorities will always belong in another role. We reject that on the side of opposition. What is our stance?

We believe that recasting minorities in roles already played by others is better than creating new lead characters. Recasting can easily be done through three broad ways. The first is the backstory, creating a pre-storyline to justify a transition. For instance, a character can have a backstory of growing up in poverty that he subsequently overcame, even though they might not have been part of the original character. Second, continuing a storyline of a particular character, where the role of a lead character can be passed on to a minority. For instance, in a very contemporary example, Captain America handing the shield to Falcon, for example. That's also a form of recasting a character. Third, alternate universes or adaptations, where conditions of lead characters are re-explored through the lens of a minority character. So there can be changes to the original story for viewers to compare and contrast.

We bring to you multiple examples. The first of which is Spider- Into the Spider-Verse, where Spider-Man is portrayed as an African-American kid in the form of Miles Morales. And also, it was able to integrate minority parts into the story. For example, Miles Morales had an uncle that played Proud of, which represents all the sort of problems that exist with African-American kids growing up in a black neighbourhood, for example, that is riddled with crime and gang incidents. We bring in another example of Othello, about how Othello can have remade plays where Othello is played as a Caucasian rather than as an African-Italian man, and his wife now becomes the African-Italian wife, that's the Mona, no thank you, rather than the Caucasian wife. The value of this analysis is that our stories remain believable and enticing to the original audience. But crucially, we can incorporate new aspects of minority culture without having to make a new rule. So we think that it is an unfair imposition on site proposition to say that there can only be visceral differences, like a change in the skin colour, but we cannot make minor tweaks to the storyline or the context. For example, because we think that all of that is within the purview of site opposition, because it uses the same character, just minor tweaks, not an entirely new character that is unheard of. That is the key distinguishing factor between the two sides. Don't let them mislead you into saying that

we can only change the skin colour or the gender of a character. Now I want to expand the criteria of this debate because the proposition seems to allude to this notion that only meaningful representation is important, no thank you. But I think when we're talking about increasing awareness about minority representation for example, it's not just about meaningful representation, it's about awareness as well and about new perspectives, about what society at large perceives about a character or a minority, how the minority therefore then goes on to interact with the majority when these new concepts are brought into the sphere.

So I have two broad arguments, two broad rebuttals for today. First, on empowering minorities, and second, on coming perception. And on the first idea of empowering minorities, recognize that their side talks about a sprinkle of representation on our side. But they themselves have no mechanism as to why the writers and the scriptwriters on site proposition won't have the same sprinkle of representation they talk about. We POI'd them about why these writers have any incentive to do so. They had no response, no structural features why the writers on site proposition who create new rules are not under the same stereotypes and the same discrimination and the same racism that they claim exists on our side. In my first argument later in my constructive, I'll prove to you why the writers on our side have even more incentive to be even more representative. Second question, on public perception. And they tell us that on our side, these characters will stick out like saw of thumbs. But I think that that is inherently racist of side composition. To say that a black James Bond has significantly different characteristics just because he's black and just because he's not James Bond anymore. I don't think that that line of argumentation has any relevance into this debate as I'll further prove in my argument how I'm able to reiterate these individuals. So my first argument on river exposures with minority representation. And here in my first argument, I'll continue to clash with the lack of mechanism from side proposition as to how to impact representation. The thesis of this argument is that recasting minorities in existing gender roles generates even more attention on minority representation. Premise, the industry of popular culture and art is ruthless, both in the production as well as the consumption stage. On production, most studios and production houses, filmmakers, have strict vetting processes for scripts because they demand security and certainty for profits. title: WSDC 2023 Round 4 - Malaysia vs Sri Lanka
description:
Vietnam World Schools Debating Championship 2023 Round 4

Motion: This house believes that the feminist movement should promote the maximisation of individual development and empowerment over solidarity among women

Proposition: Malaysia  
Opposition: Sri Lanka  

Results: Opposition won.

Disclaimer: The speakers were assigned a topic and a speaking position. Their speeches do not reflect their own personal views or opinions.

#WSDC2023 #MWS2023 #TeamMalaysia2023 #WSDC #debate
motion: This house believes that the feminist movement should prioritize individual choice over collective solidarity.

argument_units.text: The need for solidarity within the feminist movement has expired, and what remains of it is but a mere veneer for the condemnation of the most vulnerable women by the upper echelon standard in society. Proposition is the style that stands for all women and for that reason we're so proud to propose. Before I forward two substantive arguments within this speech, onto our set of big things. Firstly, what does a world where the feminist movement promote the maximization of individuals look like? We think it is one where we prioritize things like choice feminism. So there are two main defining characteristics underneath this. One, individuals in every aspect of society are left to decide what is best for them. So for instance, when it comes to social interactions, we'd be perfectly fine with women weaponizing the patriarchy for their own benefit. Or when it comes to things like economic enfranchisement, we will also be fine with women cursing a job promotion, even if it comes at the expense of another woman. Secondly, there's respect for the individual choices that individuals make. So for example, when our political opinions divulge, that is acceptable, we don't need to condemn women for it. Secondly, what is the nature of the feminist movement in the status quo? Three things. One, I'd like to point out the feminist movement is experiencing an unprecedented level of power in the status quo as a result of all-time awareness regarding necessity for things like gender equality. But two, not that many of the things that are fundamental for basic living standards, for example, marriage equality and voting rights, have already been achieved in the status quo, so there isn't as much as a need for solidarity as opposition may point out. Lastly, the biggest hurdles that the feminist movement experiences now are no longer collective systems of oppression, but rather individualistic, and we only think it's under a paradigm where we empower individual empowerment, where that can be dealt with.

Lastly, not that this debate isn't about the instances where what is good for the individual and the collective alliance, because on either side that would be symmetric. What we need to focus on is that when individual empowerment is perceived to come at the expense of solidarity, that is where the trade-off happens on the side of opposition. Two arguments can be reached. Firstly, a principle on how the maximization of individual empowerment best deals with the diverse circumstances of women, and secondly, why individual empowerment overcomes the hurdles to a success that women face. Only first argument, three parts. First of all, not that the patriarchy's enforcement of oppression is varying, so I'd just like to preface this argument by saying that gone are the days where all women are affected in the same way by coercive structures. Why is this the case? We think it's because the patriarchy's imposition of oppression is no longer universal but in fact it's subjective. To illustrate, for example, women who are conventionally attractive in the status quo are treated as sexual objects by men, but the same women who might not fit the norms of conventional beauty aren't able to enjoy things like pretty privilege. So what this shows is that social expectations have evolved to the point where oppression is individualised, and we think the best way to combat it is to allow individuals to pursue the avenues of empowerment that they deem are most suited for their circumstances. Secondly, we think solidarity on their side, as espoused by the feminist movement, merely extends the oppression that women face. Why is this the case? Well, in order for them to have things like collective solidarity, three things happen. Firstly, all women are presumed to have to operate on a collective in order to save individuals who might not know what is best for them. So what you do essentially is that you homogenise what is best for all women. So for example, a woman who chooses to don the hijab is considered to be oppressed, and individuals who might opt into things like sex work by her only fans are perceived to not want to do it. It's merely coercive. Why is this problematic? Secondly, they would institute policies that come at the expense of other women. So for example, the justification for banning things like the hijab is that it's anti-feminist and that all women are actually coerced into wearing it. The problem here that we want to highlight is that more often than not, the most privileged women who are often white and wealthy get to dictate what is best for all women because what is inherently tied to the notion of solidarity is that it entrenches a savior complex. Finally, in order to do things like maintain solidarity, there's a necessity to demonize any women who don't fit into what the collective ought to do. So you on the side of opposition want to push everyone into the same agenda in order to deter individuals who might want to opt out of it, need to do things like demonize any anomalies and that is seen exactly on the side of opposition when the movement does things like stigmatize sex workers by saying that they are coerced into it and they don't actually want to do it. It's extremely discriminatory towards them. Finally, not only the purpose of the feminist movement is to empower individuals, and insofar as the first two parts of the argument have proven that they cannot get that change that is tailored to the individual, their world actually fails women. What happens on our side when we do things that prioritize agency? One, individuals aren't shamed for pursuing things that divulge from what the collective ought to know. But secondly, because we think that individuals are the best arbiters at ascertaining what is the best form of empowerment for themselves, they are more likely going to access it on their side, compared to those when they have to compromise, and some women are inevitably going to get traded off on their side. But before I go on to the second argument, sure.
In a world where pretty privilege and

high beauty standards exist together, isn't it better for women that have pretty privilege not to exploit it to the detriment of others, and for women that cannot meet high beauty standards to have greater solidarity with those women that do conform and fight patriarchal norms together? So the issue with that is, one, you would have to force women who might not necessarily want to self-sacrifice to sacrifice on your side.

So you think that's why you're going to garner resentment within the movement. But secondly, more importantly, you think it it's far better because when at least some women can exploit their pretty privilege, get into positions of power where they actually have the force to do things like change on-the-ground policies, there's a better capacity to help women who might not necessarily benefit from things like pretty privilege.

On to the second argument explaining why individual empowerment overcomes the hurdle to a success that women face in the status quo. Firstly, I'd like to characterize the political status of the feminist movement in the status quo. So although it may be controversial to consider yourself a feminist, we have already amassed enough numbers in doing things like voting legislation into effect, garnering baseline protection for women. So what this shows is that any critical mass that opposition wants to talk about that is only achieved via solidarity is no longer necessary for the feminist movement. What we need to do instead is to combat how stereotypes that manifest on a case-by-case basis, which a narrative of solidarity uniquely cannot cater to, because you aren't focusing on the individual, you make all women focus on one thing. Secondly, look at all the labels that incapacitate women are actually combated under our narrative. And I'd like to highlight something here, which is that individual empowerment under a capitalistic system, which exists on both sides of the house, by the way, will always come at the expense of someone else because resources are zero-sum and someone will always have to lose out. So we don't care if the structure is contributing to stereotypes. What we uniquely prove is how our narrative can deal with these stereotypes, but they can't. How are women empowered on our side? Three things. One, when we don't shame women from prioritising individual upliftment, we think that is when they're more willing to accept things like job promotions, without feeling a sense of guilt that the feminist movement says that you have deprived another woman of that opportunity. Shame on you. But suddenly, traits associated with men no longer become exclusive to men only when women are also able to ascend to positions of power. So for example, a woman is no longer considered bossy. She can also be considered a leader when she is the CEO of a company. But thirdly, for those in the most vulnerable positions in society, what we tell these individuals is that the only obligation they owe is to them themselves and they don't need to sacrifice more in order to be considered a good feminist. What we tell these individuals is that the only obligation they owe is to them themselves and they don't need to sacrifice more in order to be considered a good feminist. Here is the comparative that opposition will have to defend. We think their rate of progress is actually far slower. Why? Three reasons. One, whenever a woman has the opportunity to ascend the corporate ladder on their side, the movement tells her she should wait because if she accepts this promotion, she deprives another woman of that opportunity. So certainly, on that, we think there's less ascension to power because resources are spent on attempting to uplift everyone and their inevitably rationed on their side. Lastly, in their best case, when there are women who land into powerful positions, you don't spotlight these individuals because their participation contributes to oppression. Finally, we think opposition forwards an extremely damaging perception of the movement, that we are all the same, we have to fight for the same thing, but we don't suffer from this because our narrative is one that's focused on how all individuals deserve the ability to individually empower themselves.
